title: Hello!
text:
I’m Olivia Pietrzak, an aspiring data sciencist pursuing my master’s degree in Social Data Analytics and Research at the University of Texas at Dallas. I graduated with honors from the economics department at UTD in December 2022, and I currently work as a Data Analyst at Dallas College within the Strategic Research and Analytics department. In this role, I use data to help college leadership identify and dismantle barriers to student success.
My research passions converge at the crossroads of economic justice, education, and labor economics. I am excited to contribute to meaningful projects that make a positive impact, I am committed to leveraging data insights to drive positive change in these crucial areas.
Please feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn!

title: Knowledge Mining: Homework 1
text:
Group Project Planning
Cristina, Dagmar, and I met today to discuss the project. We identified human rights/international institutions or education as potential research topics for our class project.
There was some confusion about Dr. Ho’s expectations for the project, so Dagmar and I intend to arrive early at Wednesday’s class to try to meet with Dr. Ho. We will then reconvene as a group to narrow down potential subjects and start to outline our project.

title: Information Management Homework 1
text: Please find a link to my Slides presentation here.

title: KM Prepare for Class 4
text:
Look for an example of applying machine learning methods to perform prediction.
Olivia’s definition of ML prediction: formulating a hypothesis based on ML techniques (not trying to explain a concept).
Maybe the drop-out question that we’ve been considering at work: what factors cause a student to drop-out?
Explain:

When to do data mining?

In my mind, data mining is a way to understand the trends within the data that you have, and ought to be done with all data before you begin working with it. I would consider that summary statistics, correlation, visualization, and normalcy checks would all be ways of performing data mining.

When to do machine learning?

Once you understand the nature of the data that you are working with, you would select a ML model to use, and execute the method. You wouldn’t want to build a hypothesis before you create the ML model – the model isn’t intended to confirm your hypothesis, but rather to help you create one.

What is the data source?

I suppose for my research question (what factors influence a student to drop out) we would want a diverse set of variables that relate to a student’s life, both academic and personal (examples could include grades earned in class, class attendance, work hours in a week, number of children, transportation method for commuting, etc.). We would want many observations of students as we could get. You could use a variety of techniques to gather this data (interview, registrar/student records, etc.).

What is the variable to be predicted?

The variables that are statistically more signifcant when we are looking at students that drop out. We ultimately want to know whether or not a student will drop out, but this isn’t going to be the output of our ML, the factors are.

Or is there none?

I’m not sure why there would be none…it seems like there out to be some sort of predicted variable, otherwise why bother with ML?

Why would a traditional statistical model be better or worse?

If you want to understand how much an independent variables affects your dependent variables, you should choose a traditional model.
If you want to understand what different independent variables should be considered, you should choose a machine learning model.

title: Knowledge Mining - Prepare for Class #5
text:
Assigned Reading – Text Mining with R: A Tidy Approach
Identify a topic you’d like to analyze:
News data and op-ed data about neural implants and embryonic gene editing.
This data would be helpful for our class project – we are going to examine these topics.
